tasks.title: Investigate semantic search relevance for domain-specific queries
tasks.description:
During dog-fooding, searching for 'security test fuzzing' returned staleness tests instead of actual security-related code. The search seems to weight common terms like 'test' too heavily.

Investigation areas:
- Query expansion may be pulling in too many generic terms
- TF-IDF weighting may not properly discount common programming terms
- Domain-specific boosting could improve relevance for security/testing queries

Related: The code_concepts.py has programming synonyms but may need security-specific terms.

Discovered during: Dog-fooding session 2025-12-14

tasks.title: Memory consolidation suggestions
tasks.description:
Analyze memories to suggest consolidation opportunities:

1. Find memories with high term overlap (similar topics)
2. Identify repeated concepts across multiple entries
3. Suggest creating concept documents from clusters
4. Track 'memory age' - old unconsolidated memories

Algorithm:
- Use existing Louvain clustering on memory documents
- Memories in same cluster = consolidation candidates
- High PageRank terms across cluster = concept name

Output:
- 'These 5 memories all discuss PageRank, consider creating concepts/pagerank.md'
- 'Memory from 2025-12-10 has 80% overlap with 2025-12-14, merge?'

CLI: python scripts/suggest_consolidation.py

tasks.description:

Changes needed:

2. Update /knowledge-transfer command

Example: 2025-12-14-dogfooding-a1b2.md

The session ID approach mirrors the proven task system design.

tasks.title: Audit markdown files for staleness
tasks.description:
Review all markdown documentation for outdated content.

Files to audit:
- README.md - main project readme
- CLAUDE.md - development guide
- CONTRIBUTING.md - contribution guide
- docs/*.md - all documentation files
- samples/**/*.md - sample documents

Check for:
1. Outdated code examples (do they still run?)
2. Missing new features (text-as-memories, security, skills)
3. Broken internal links ([[wiki-style]] and markdown links)
4. Incorrect file paths or line numbers
5. Deprecated APIs still documented
6. Missing new configuration options
7. Outdated task references

Create a staleness report:
- List files with issues
- Categorize by severity (broken vs outdated vs minor)
- Link to specific lines needing updates

Consider adding a CI check for:
- Broken markdown links
- Code blocks that don't parse
- References to non-existent files

tasks.title: Add markdown link checker to CI
tasks.description:
Add automated checking for broken links in markdown files.

Tools to consider:
- markdown-link-check (npm)
- mlc (rust-based, fast)
- lychee (rust-based, comprehensive)

CI integration:
```yaml
markdown-lint:
  runs-on: ubuntu-latest
  steps:
    - uses: actions/checkout@v4
    - name: Check markdown links
      uses: gaurav-nelson/github-action-markdown-link-check@v1
      with:
        use-quiet-mode: 'yes'
        config-file: '.markdown-link-check.json'
```

Config file should:
- Ignore external URLs (or check with timeout)
- Check internal file references
- Check anchor links (#section-name)
- Whitelist known-good external domains

Also check:
- [[wiki-style]] links resolve to real files
- Code file references (cortical/foo.py:123) exist
